title: Spanish I
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Spanish to explore the basic features of the Spanish language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Spanish through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Spanish grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type. Can introduce and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has. Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help. - Listening: Can understand familiar words and very basic phrases concerning him/herself, his/her family and immediate concrete surroundings when people speak slowly and clearly. - Reading: Can understand familiar names, words and very simple sentences, for example on notices and posters or in catalogues. - Spoken interaction: Can interact in a simple way provided the other person is prepared to repeat or rephrase things at a slower rate of speech and help me formulate what he/she is trying to say. He/she can ask and answer simple questions in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics. - Spoken production: Can use simple phrases and sentences to describe where he/she lives and people he/she knows. - Writing: Can write a short, simple postcard, for example sending holiday greetings. Can fill in forms with personal details, for example entering his/her name, nationality and address on a hotel registration form.

title: Spanish Civilization and Its Languages I
description: This course offers a broad interdisciplinary introduction to the Hispanic civilization. It surveys the realities of Hispanic cultures and societies through the examination of their evolution, geography, languages, economy, social configurations, artistic ways of expressions, gastronomy, forms of leisure and celebrations. It attempts to foster a general understanding of the connections and the differences of Hispanic cultures and societies geographically separated widely apart. The course is taught in an interactive manner which engages students in classroom discussions and projects related to Hispanic issues of their interest. No prior knowledge in Spanish is required.
outcome: The aim of this course is to let students explore different aspects of these cultures and societies and expose them to diverse beliefs, social realities, backgrounds and attitudes, while comparing with Hong Kong and Chinese customs and traditions. It is important to remark that only 40 million of speakers out of 400 live in Spain, being Latin America the place with more native Spanish speakers in the world. Although the course can not cover all aspects, it will give students an idea about culture, politics, clothing, food, history, music, art, climate, landscapes, economy and literature. The objective is to stimulate students’ thinking about these cultures as well as their own in order to broaden their horizon and bring them the opportunity to increase their knowledge about these cultures and countries. At the end of the course students should be able to have a deeper understanding of these Spanish speaking countries.
syllabus: • Presentation of the course (principles of the course; assessment scheme; time management; schedule for presentations; questionnaires) • Clichés/stereotypes about Latin America, Spain  and Chinese people (brainstorming). Spanish in the world.  • Image of Spain in the world. Language policy: Spanish as the official language • Present and discuss in class information about Spain. • General facts. Review of its history, folklore, politics, literature and modern society.  • Image of Latin America.  • Present and discuss in class information about the countries of Central America.  Countries: Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panamá • Present and discuss information about the Spanish Speaking countries of the Caribbean Countries: Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico and Cuba • Information and in class discussion about the countries of South America • Countries: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, Venezuela. • FINAL PROJECT
required_readings: Course materials: Assigned texts and different handouts will be distributed to students according to the topics studied in class. All kinds of medium will be used such as PowerPoint, movies, newspapers articles, etc.  Texts: The Cambridge Companion to Modern Latin American Culture by John King (Cambridge University Press) Synopsis: Specially-commissioned essays analyze Latin American history, politics, art and literature from the nineteenth century to the present and reveal the common heritage of pre-Columbian and colonial Latin America. Although the Portuguese and Spanish-speaking states created in the early 1820s differed greatly geographically and demographically (in ethnic composition and economic resources), they also shared distinct historical and cultural traits. A chronology and guide to further reading make this volume an invaluable introduction to the rich and varied culture of modern Latin America.  Spain: A History by Raymond Carr (Oxford University Press)  Synopsis: In this up-to-date and engaging tour of Spain through the ages, one of the world's leading authorities on the history of Spain, Sir Raymond Carr, provides an authoritative overview of a country that has played a vital role in the history of the Western world. He tells of prehistoric Spain and of the imposition of Roman rule, which created the idea of Hispania as a single entity. There are knowledgeable discussions of the Visigoth monarchy, Moorish Spain, the establishment of an empire, and the eighteenth-century Enlightenment. Carr examines not only the political and economic development of Spain, but also the extraordinary artistic and literary achievements of the Spanish people. He charts the rise and fall of liberalism in the nineteenth century, and the subsequent period of political instability culminating in the Civil War and authoritarian rule. The book concludes with a look at modern Spain as a fully integrated and enthusiastic member of the European community. Attractively illustrated throughout, Spain: A History is the best historical account of Spain currently available for general readers.

title: Spanish II
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in SPAN1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Spanish in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Spanish culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Spanish while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should:  1.Be able to confidently distinguish Spanish sounds and pronounce them in a way that other Spanish speakers will be able to understand  2.Have acquired a core active vocabulary of Spanish of over 300 words  3.Have improved the skills to make accurate predictions on the meaning of words and sentences through the context or their cognates in other languages known 4.Have reviewed the previously studied grammar points and expanded the basic intuitions on the Spanish morphology and syntax and reviewed and fixed already learnt basic grammar patterns 5.Be able to produce and understand simple messages in Spanish and interactively communicate in certain social situations with a basic awareness of the pragmatic rules involved 6.Be able to write simple compositions in Spanish (description, narrative, dialogue and letter form)

title: Spanish III
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken SPAN3000(2002),3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: SPAN2000 (1002) or 2050 (1010)
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: By the end of the course, students should:  1. have increased a core active vocabulary of Spanish of around 100-150 words;  2. have developed skills to make accurate predictions on the meaning of words and sentences through the context or their cognates in other languages known; 3. have developed basic intuitions on the Spanish morphology and syntax and learned basic grammar patterns; 4. be able to produce and understand simple messages in Spanish and interactively communicate in certain social situations with a basic awareness of the pragmatic rules involved; 5. be able to write simple compositions in Spanish about themselves, family and the world around them.

title: Hispanic Cinema
description: This course explores the history and aesthetic qualities, as well as cultural and social aspects of cinema in the Spanish speaking world. It is designed to provide students with a basic knowledge of the cinematographic scene in the Hispanic world, with special attention to the films made in Spain, Cuba, Mexico and Argentina. It should also enable students to 'read' those films as both reflections on and critiques of Hispanic society and culture, and as part of a global world. This course is designed for students who are interested in exploring the growing international popularity of Hispanic. All films are with English subtitles. No knowledge of Spanish is required. Screening of movies will take place outside the class.

Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.

title: Spanish V
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken SPAN3002 or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: SPAN3000 (2002) or SPAN3050 (2010)
description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in Spanish with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Spanish-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should: 1. Improve their communication skills in Spanish: oral and written comprehension and social  interaction. 2. Increase their working vocabulary and their competence of Spanish Grammar 3. Be able to express themselves both individually and parts of a group in certain social  situations, as well as defend your opinion and show disagreement in a debating exercise 4. Be able to write compositions according to the level of knowledge of the Spanish language   acquired. 5. Be able to be comfortably make use of past, present and future tenses according to the   context. 6. Have a basic knowledge of some events and key people of the history in Spanish speaking countries

title: Spanish VI

description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Spanish language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of Spanish. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Spanish and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Spanish-speaking societies.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should:  1. Have widely improved their competence of Spanish grammar and increased their working vocabulary.  2. Have improved their communication skills in Spanish (oral and written production and  comprehension) according to the needs of the social interaction involved.  3. Be able to apply the language and the contents learnt to real situations, using it to relate to, reflect on  and analyze past and current global issues involving the Spanish-speaking world.  4. Be able to reflect on strategic skills to satisfy the needs of communication in the foreign language and  to make their learning more autonomous and long-lasting.  5. Be familiar with the format of the official exam for proficiency of Spanish as a foreign language  (DELE).

title: Spanish through Film
description: This course integrates language and content learning. It is based on a set of topics that will be introduced through the analysis of selected films. The course will approach these topics from both cultural and linguistic perspectives. This course aims to consolidate and extend students’ existing language skills, providing them with a solid understanding of Spanish culture. Special emphasis is placed on conversational fluency, grammatical accuracy and vocabulary acquisition. The course will be structured around 6 films which will provide the basis for various activities and debates that will help students develop their listening, speaking, writing, reading and interacting skills, as well as their ability to describe analyse, and reflect upon other cultural manifestations.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should have developed or improved their: - Ability to communicate and participate in regular discussions on diverse topics. - Capacity for close analysis of visual material and comparative analysis. - Ability to describe, analyse and criticize diverse cultural manifestations. - Ability to reflect upon their own learning process. - Spanish language skills in the four language domains.
syllabus: Spanish Civil War. - Exploring relevant historical events Work Art / Artists - Approaching the diversity of art. Historical events its consequences and its reflection in master pieces of art. Migrations. - Cultural shocks. Adaptation to a new and foreign environment. Solitude. Generational conflicts. Homesickness. American dream.

title: Business Spanish I
description: This course is designed to introduce to students the genuine communicative situations in the setting of the Spanish-speaking business world. It aims at developing the basic language proficiency (speaking, listening, reading and writing) that enable one to confidently handle typical business transactions in Spanish. Students will be engaged in active practice. Role plays will be used to simulate a wide range of business situations. Specific features of Spanish business discourse will be put into practice. The course will also encourage learners to become more aware of the cultural factors in the business practices of Spanish-speaking countries, and the importance of improving the cross-cultural communication skills.

title: Spanish V & VI
requirements: Not for students who have taken SPAN3001 or 3002. Prerequisite: SPAN3000 (2002) or SPAN3050 (2010).
description: This is a summer intensive Spanish language course, covering the full syllabus of SPAN3001 and 3002.
outcome: In this course we will continue to combine practical-oriented work with grammar-focused. Creativity and team-work will be once more a fundamental part of our SPA courses as we expect students to achieve higher outcomes. By the end of the course, students should:  1. Have widely improved their competence of Spanish grammar and increased their working vocabulary.  2. Have improved their communication skills in Spanish (oral and written production and comprehension) according to the needs of the social interaction involved.  3. Be able to apply the language and the contents learnt to real situations, using it to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current global issues involving the Spanish-speaking world. 4. Be able to reflect on strategic skills to satisfy the needs of communication in the foreign language and to make their learning more autonomous and long-lasting. 5. Be familiar with the format of the official exam for proficiency of Spanish as a foreign language (DELE).
syllabus: SPAN3051      Lecciones Speech acts Grammar and vocabulary   Unidad 1. VOLVER A EMPEZAR (Starting anew) - Talking about your personal background. - Telling anecdotes. - Describing your daily activities in the past tense. - Referring to actions. - Review and practice of the simple past tense regular and irregular verbs. - The Present Perfect, the Imperfect and the Indefinite Past forms. - The verbal periphrasis: empezar a (start to), acabar de (finish), volver a (to do something again), dejar de (stop doing something), etc.   Unidad 2. PROHIBIDO PROHIBIR (Forbidden to forbid) - Expressing obligations and prohibitions. - Constructing impersonal sentences. - Talking about habits. - The modal verbs. - The impersonal constructions. - The Present Subjunctive. - Adverbial phrases: es normal (normal)/ habitual (usual)/ raro (rare), etc. - Quantifiers and expressions of quantity: todo el mundo (everybody)/ la mayoría (the majority)/ muchos (many) / algunos (some).   Unidad 3. MENSAJES (Messages) - Conveying messages. - Applying communicative strategies to different situations. - Talking on the phone. - Taking and leaving messages. - Reported speech and direct speech. - Clauses and reporting verbs (contestar, decir, explicar, preguntar, etc). - Verbs expressing intention: recomendar (to recommend), sugerir (to suggest), preguntar (to ask), insistir (to insist), etc.   i   Unidad 4. VA Y LE DICE… (Now go and tell…) - Summarizing information and events. - Writing a film synopsis. - Telling jokes. . - Review of the Present tense. - Direct and Indirect Object Pronouns. - The connectors. - Summarizing phrases.   Unidad 5. ¡BASTA YA! (Enough already!) - Expressing wishes and needs. - Lodging complaints. - Assessing situations and events. - The Present Subjunctive. - The subjunctive and the infinitive usages.   Unidad 6. EL TURISTA ACCIDENTAL (The accidental tourist) - Telling anecdotes and stories. - Showing interest in a subject. - Expressing cause and effect. - The combination of different verb tenses in oral and written discourse. - The pluperfect. - Expressions of preferences. - Travel vocabulary. - Positive and negative interjections.   Unidad 7. TENEMOS QUE HABLAR (We need to talk) - Taking part in formal and informal conversations. - Expressing positive and negative feelings. - Showing interest and indifference. - Expressing opinion, agreement and disagreement. - Opposing views and defending arguments about issues in mini-debates. - Sentence connectors: además (furthermore), entonces (therefore), de todas maneras (anyway), etc.) - Expressions for softening quarrels and misunderstandings, showing anger, saying positive comments, etc. - Key mini-debate jargon.   Unidad 9. MISTERIOS Y ENIGMAS (Mysteries and enigmas) - Making hypotheses and conjectures. - Describing mysterious and supernatural events. - Expressing beliefs. - Simple Future tense vs. Compound Future tense - Supernatural world vocabulary. - The different degrees of certainty. - The Indicative vs. the Subjunctive   Unidad 10. BUENAS NOTICIAS (Good news) - Writing a news story - Delivering news. - Deciding who could participate in a reality show. - The Conditional tense - The passive voice - Vocabulary related to mass media   OTHER ACTIVITIES Spanish Film Festival
